SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. He reports feeling out of sorts lately, with fatigue, lightheadedness, and bloating. These symptoms have been present for about five weeks. He has been working on home renovations and eating out more frequently due to kitchen construction, which has affected his diet. He denies fever, chills, and abdominal pain but endorses shortness of breath during exertion and slight chest cramps that resolve after about an hour. He also reports a slight cough.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Fatigue, lightheadedness.
• Cardiovascular: Shortness of breath during exertion, slight chest cramps.
• Respiratory: Slight cough.
• Gastrointestinal: Bloating.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygenation within normal limits.
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to 8 centimeters.
• Cardiovascular: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive Heart Failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by physical exam and chest x-ray findings.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Monitor weight daily and report any weight gain or shortness of breath. Order another echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure appears well-managed at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily. Continue to record blood pressures at home and report any elevations through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She states she was changing a light bulb on a ladder and stumbled, twisting her knee while trying to catch her fall. The incident occurred yesterday. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help. She denies any other injuries. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin. She has a past surgical history of a rhinoplasty. She denies any allergies.

EXAM:

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial meniscus area. Pain is elicited upon flexion and valgus stressing of the knee. Normal sensation is present. No calf pain.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present.

IMPRESSION:

Acute medial meniscus sprain/strain.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her in a knee brace and provide crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for reevaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg, to be taken every 6 hours with food, for a two-week supply.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

The patient states he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. This happened on Saturday morning, and he felt a pop in his lower back. He had to lie down for about an hour before the pain was relieved, and it has been stiff ever since. He reports taking Tylenol, ibuprofen, and using icy heat, but these did not provide significant relief. He experienced tingling in his right toes until Sunday afternoon.

Regarding his diabetes, he admits to having a sweet tooth and not having the best diet recently. For his hypertension, he monitors his blood pressure readings at home during the week but tends to forget on weekends. He is taking his medication as prescribed. For his osteoarthritis, he experiences occasional aggravation but overall manages it well.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies weight loss. Denies fever or chills.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses lower back pain. Endorses tingling in right toes.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic heart murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Examination of his back reveals pain to palpation at the lumbar spine. Pain with flexion and extension of the back. Negative straight leg raise.

Results:

Back X-ray, ordered and obtained in the office today, is unremarkable with good bony alignment and no fracture present.

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports feeling a 'pop' and immediate pain while lifting heavy boxes. He has tried Tylenol and ibuprofen without significant relief.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue icing the area and avoid strenuous activity. Refer to physical therapy for further evaluation and treatment.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: He has been compliant with medication but admits to recent poor dietary choices. His recent hemoglobin A1c was 8.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily. Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings have been running on the high side, and his blood pressure was elevated in the office today.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has been managing his osteoarthritis well and does not require further workup at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam.

Regarding his depression, he has been taking Prozac and reports no recent incidents. He states that his depression is well-managed and maintained.

Regarding his hypertension, he is taking Norvasc regularly during the business week but admits to occasionally forgetting on weekends. He reports that his blood pressure has been mostly okay.

The patient had a lobectomy a couple of years ago. He reports no significant issues with shortness of breath, except during high pollen season and when running in humid conditions.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion due to pollen.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain. Reports shortness of breath with exertion.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath at rest.
• Psychiatric: Endorses depression, well-managed with medication.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neurological/Psychological: Appropriate mood and affect.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

Electrocardiogram: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerning findings.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression.
   • Medical Reasoning: Well-managed with Prozac.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily. Refill ordered.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Encouraged to continue current management strategies.

2. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Controlled with Norvasc.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Norvasc as prescribed.
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.

3. Status post lobectomy.
   • Medical Reasoning: No significant issues reported, and chest X-ray is normal.
   • Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon needed.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right index finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right index finger pain after a skiing accident. She reports that she was skiing over the weekend and got her strap caught on her finger while going over a mogul, causing her finger to bend back. The incident occurred on Sunday. She has tried ice and ibuprofen for pain relief, but the pain persists.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Miralax

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Constipation, appendectomy at age 18

EXAM:

Examination of the right index finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right index finger, 3 views obtained on today's visit show no fractures and normal alignment.

IMPRESSION:

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend an aluminum foam splint and a prescription for Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for one week. If the pain does not improve, the patient is advised to call and return for further evaluation. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia. She reports feeling fatigued, feverish with chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, and headaches. She also experiences cold intolerance and worsening anxiety and depression. She has been anemic since the age of 13 and had a hysterectomy in 1996. She denies any recent gastrointestinal bleeding or urinary tract bleeding.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Endorses fatigue, fever, and chills.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath and wheezing.
• Neurological: Endorses headaches.
• Psychiatric: Endorses worsening anxiety and depression.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Normal without any significant findings.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia.

Iron deficiency anemia.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has been dealing with anemia since the age of 13. She has been taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets twice daily and over-the-counter vitamin B12 supplements.
• Additional Testing: We will schedule an upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or gastrointestinal bleeding. If these tests are inconclusive, a capsule endoscopy will be considered.
• Specialist Referrals: We will refer her to a hematologist for further evaluation and possible intravenous iron treatment or other interventions to improve her iron storage.
• Patient Education and Counseling: The patient should continue taking her iron pills with orange juice to enhance iron absorption. She should do this for the next 8-12 weeks, after which we will reassess her blood work.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male who presents to the clinic for consultation regarding a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. The patient was referred by Dr. Henry Howard for possible surgical intervention. Mr. Ward initially presented to his primary care provider on 3/1/21 with complaints of worsening headaches over the past few months. He denies any history of headaches. His past clinical history is unremarkable.

Workup for worsening headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where the pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. Pertinent labs and radiology studies were reviewed, including a pituitary hormone profile demonstrating a low TSH, with all other results normal. The MRI reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm.

The patient reports headaches located behind his eyes, described as a dull nagging ache, with a gradual onset and worsening over time. The headaches are worse in the morning and last a few hours at a time. He denies any other symptoms, such as feeling sick, fever, rashes, neck stiffness, numbness, weakness, or passing out. However, he has noticed bumping into door frames recently.

PAST HISTORY

Unremarkable.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Computer programmer, married for 25 years, recently bought a small house. Adopted, so family medical history is unknown.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

None.

RESULTS

MRI brain with contrast from 3/4/21: Pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm.

ASSESSMENT

• Pituitary adenoma.

PLAN

1. Recommend surgical intervention to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa due to symptomatic optic chiasmal compression.
2. Refer the patient to the eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to assess peripheral vision before and after surgery.
3. Schedule surgery and visual field test appointments.
4. Counsel the patient on the risks and benefits of the transsphenoidal approach for surgery.
5. Encourage the patient to call if they have any questions or concerns.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 52-year-old female who presents for follow-up after an ER visit for chest pain in October 2020. The patient experienced chest pain for four days, which was located in the center of her chest behind her breastbone. The pain was sharp and felt worse with eating. She also had difficulty swallowing during that time. The patient visited the ER, where they performed an EKG and blood tests, which were normal. The ER suspected a GI issue and referred her to our clinic. The patient has not had any chest pain since the initial episode.

The patient has a past medical history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Abdomen
• Lower Abdomen: No pain or tenderness.
• Upper Abdomen: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 52-year-old female who presents for follow-up after an ER visit for chest pain. The chest pain has resolved since the initial episode, and the patient has not had any additional episodes. The ER ruled out heart issues with testing. Possible etiologies for her chest pain include GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal causes, and anxiety. The patient mentioned going through a stressful job transition during the time of her chest pain, which could have contributed to her symptoms.

Given the patient's lack of symptoms for the past three months, we discussed the option of performing an EGD or upper endoscopy to evaluate her esophagus and stomach. However, the patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any recurrence or change. She will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Evaluation of kidney function in a patient with Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome, who presents today for evaluation of her kidney function. She is a twin, born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation, with a birth weight of 4 pounds, 8 ounces. She has a history of feeding difficulties, reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will soon start speech therapy. She has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, who mentioned possible kidney anomalies associated with her syndrome.

The patient has 8-10 wet diapers per day and drinks a combination of pea protein milk, water, and diluted juice. She has no known family history of kidney failure, dialysis, or transplant.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Katherine is a well-nourished female who is slightly fussy when examined. Her eyes appear small, and she has mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms. She has normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Katherine is a 22-month-old former 34 and 3-week-old twin with Smith-Magenis Syndrome. Several organ systems can be affected by this chromosomal deletion syndrome, including congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract.

We will obtain a screening of the kidneys by ultrasound today. If there are abnormalities on the kidney ultrasound, we will determine next steps and future follow-up. The family lives in Dallas, Georgia, so her follow-up should be at the town center location.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana, a 35-year-old female, presents to the clinic today for evaluation of right wrist pain. The onset of her pain began when she slipped on the stairs while doing laundry and tried to catch herself with her arms. She reports that her right wrist started to hurt severely and became swollen. The patient rates her pain level as a 9 out of 10. She has been icing her wrist, using an ace wrap, and taking ibuprofen, which provided minimal relief. The injury occurred yesterday morning. The patient denies any previous injuries to this arm.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain.
Skin: Positive swelling and bruising in the right wrist area.
Neurological: Reports mild tingling in fingers.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
Temp: 97.2°F
RR: 20

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Capillary refill is normal. No carotid bruit.
NEURO: Normal sensation. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.
MSK: Examination of the right wrist reveals obvious swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness on palpation throughout. Pain on flexion, extension, radial deviation, and ulnar deviation. Limited ability to make a tight fist. Bony crepitus present.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist taken in office today reveals a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her symptoms are consistent with a Colles' fracture. I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively at first, with a brace for her right wrist. We will schedule surgery as soon as possible. In the meantime, I will prescribe 50 mg of Ultram every six hours for pain management. Post-surgery, the patient will be referred to physical therapy for rehabilitation. The patient will follow up in one month to assess her progress and discuss her upcoming vacation plans.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to continue icing her wrist and taking pain medication as prescribed. She should follow up in one month for a progress assessment.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain after a fall.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, currently on 20 mg Lisinopril.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports working on his property when the injury occurred.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chest pain, and shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain and swelling.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg
Heart rate: Not provided
Respiration: Not provided
No fever.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort.
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Right knee: Pain to palpation on the medial aspect, pain with flexion and extension, edema, and effusion.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed in office today. These reveal no fractures or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient reports a fall with a twisting motion, resulting in pain and swelling in the right knee.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and swelling. Provide a knee brace for support and recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes at a time, 3-4 times daily. Advise the patient to elevate and rest the leg.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a history of hypertension and is currently on 20 mg Lisinopril. Blood pressure was elevated at 150/70 mmHg during the visit.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg and provide a referral to nutrition counseling to help improve the patient's diet and potentially reduce the need for medication.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any improvement. He denies any specific injury; however, he has been renovating his basement and suspects that it might be related to that activity. He does not recall hitting or falling onto the left shoulder. The patient states he is very active and has experienced left shoulder pain before that usually resolves with Tylenol.

The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. The pain is constant. He states the pain is primarily located in the left shoulder and denies it radiates down into the left arm. The patient also reports difficulty sleeping secondary to the pain. He has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left knee pain. The pain occurs occasionally, less than once a day, and is described as the whole kneecap feeling unstable. The pain comes and goes quickly, and the patient has not taken any medications for it. The patient denies any history of injury to the knee and has not experienced any popping sensations. The knee pain has not significantly interfered with her daily activities, but she is concerned about an upcoming trip involving walking and line dancing.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, diabetes mellitus.

MEDICATIONS

Farxiga, amlodipine, lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, metformin.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left knee pain and instability. Denies any other joint pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital signs: Temperature 98.2, pulse 72, respirations 16, blood pressure 122/70.

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.

Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

Musculoskeletal: Left knee exam - no ecchymosis, edema, or effusion; no pain to palpation of the left medial knee; no decreased range of motion; negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain - likely arthritis.
2. Hypertension.
3. Diabetes mellitus.

PLAN

1. For left knee pain, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider physical therapy to strengthen the muscles around the knee.
2. Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Order hemoglobin A1c and lipid panel to assess diabetes management and consider adjustments to metformin if necessary.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Sore throat and cough.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer, currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. She reports a sore throat and a dry cough for the past few days.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient has a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule, biopsy positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue.
Respiratory: Reports dry cough and sore throat.
Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea or vomiting.

VITALS

Oxygen saturation: Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Bilateral crackles on lung auscultation.
Skin: Erythema on the anterior left side of the chest, possibly related to radiation.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Lung cancer.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient is currently undergoing chemotherapy with cisplatin and etoposide and receiving radiation therapy.
- Medical Treatment: Continue current chemotherapy regimen and radiation therapy. Repeat imaging after completion of radiation therapy to assess tumor response.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's cough and crackles on lung auscultation are suggestive of radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation.

3. Painful swallowing.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's sore throat may be related to inflammation in the esophagus.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow four times a day to alleviate pain and facilitate eating and drinking.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low Immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports frequent colds during the winter season. Patient's family owns a donut shop. Patient denies any family history of immune deficiencies.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient recently diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes and started on Metformin.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: No fever.
Respiratory: Reports frequent colds during winter.
Gastrointestinal: Denies frequent diarrhea or abdominal infections.

VITALS

All vitals within normal range.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.
Respiratory: Lungs clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
Abdominal: Soft, non-tender.

LAB RESULTS

IgA level found to be low.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Low IgA level.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's lab results consistent with IgA deficiency, a common immunodeficiency. Patient does not report frequent infections beyond typical winter colds.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the nature of IgA deficiency and its potential implications. Advised the patient to watch for infections that do not resolve or are difficult to control, as well as any significant changes in abdominal symptoms.
- Medical Treatment: Additional blood work will be ordered to check other antibodies. Instructed the patient to inform healthcare providers of their IgA deficiency if they require blood products in the future.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow pain. The patient reports that he has been experiencing right elbow pain for approximately four days. He has recently been engaging in pottery and ceramics, which he believes may have contributed to the pain. The pain is localized to the inside of his right elbow and sometimes radiates down into his forearm. The pain is rated as a 6/10 and has been keeping him up at night, as well as affecting his ability to perform certain activities. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief, which has provided minimal relief.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient has recently been engaging in pottery and ceramics.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that he has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Within normal limits.
MSK: Examination of the right elbow reveals moderate tenderness of the medial epicondyle, pain with palpation, pain with pronation, and pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right elbow were obtained and reviewed in the office today. These reveal no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Right medial epicondylitis.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we had a discussion in regards to his current symptoms. The following plan was established:

1. Rest the right elbow and wear a sling while awake.
2. Apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes, three times a day.
3. Take ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours with food for one week.
4. Hold off on pottery work for the next couple of weeks.
5. Follow-up appointment in one week to evaluate progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency department follow up.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension and recent hospitalization for congestive heart failure.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Reports occasional chest pain, thought to be heartburn.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath during recent episode.
Genitourinary: No issues reported.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: 98.7 degrees F
Heart Rate: 72 bpm
Oxygen Saturation: 96%

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: This appears to have been caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue making dietary modifications, including limiting sodium intake. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily. Patient advised to weigh themselves daily and call if they gain 3 pounds in 2 days.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: This has been poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed dietary modifications as noted above.
- Medical Treatment: Continue on Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 3 months.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Kidney stones.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of kidney stones. The patient was referred from his primary care physician. He has been experiencing sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain is intermittent and worsens when it occurs. He reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine at times. He has taken Tylenol for the pain, but it has not been effective. He feels nauseated but has not vomited. The patient has a family history of kidney stones, and he has had them before but was able to pass them.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Abdominal: Reports right-sided abdominal pain and burning sensation during urination.

VITALS

Not provided in the dialogue.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs. Positive CVA tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

The CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Right kidney stone.

PLAN

We reviewed the patient's CT results in detail today. I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively. I have prescribed the patient oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours for pain. He may continue to take Tylenol between the oxycodone doses for any breakthrough pain. The patient will be provided with a strainer to use when urinating to catch the stone when it passes. I have also recommended that we obtain a BMP, urinalysis, and urine culture to evaluate for any signs of infection.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me in 1 to 2 weeks to check on his progress. If his symptoms have not improved, we will discuss further treatment options including lithotripsy or ureteroscopy. The patient is advised to contact me if he experiences worsening symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right foot non-healing ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a 79-year-old male who presents today for evaluation of a right foot ulcer. He reports having the ulcer for about six weeks, which he first noticed after wearing a pair of tight shoes. The ulcer started as a blister and progressed to an unroofed wound with thick, soft, mushy skin and yellow drainage. He has been experiencing a foul smell from the wound and has had a fever of 99.7°F and chills. He started antibiotics six days ago, but the wound has turned black around the edges and he has been experiencing cramping in his calf muscle. He also reports a red streak coming up the front part of his ankle along the inside portion of his calf muscle, which is very hot.

He is a diabetic with a history of diabetic neuropathy. His blood sugars have been trending in the 300-400 range for the past two weeks, with one spike at 500-600. His last A1C was 6.7.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys hiking and recently hiked to Charlie's Bunion. He wears diabetic shoes and inserts, which he changes every 3-4 months.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking antibiotics for the foot ulcer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Fever and chills.
Cardiovascular: No chest pain.
Respiratory: Coughing and difficulty catching breath when walking.
Skin: Right foot ulcer with black edges and red streak up the calf.
Neurological: Diabetic neuropathy.

VITALS

Fever: Present
Blood pressure: Within normal range
Heart rate: Within normal range

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses. Non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.
RESPIRATORY: Coughing and difficulty catching breath when walking.
SKIN: 2x2 cm necrotic wound on right heel with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, erythemia, and foul odor. No bony exposure.
NECK: No jugular venous distention or carotid bruits.

ASSESSMENT

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer, right foot
2. Diabetes with recent blood sugar instability
3. Possible cellulitis

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to his current symptoms. We discussed the following plan:

1. Order a test to check blood supply for the wound.
2. Perform debridement today in the office.
3. Obtain a culture and consider different antibiotic therapy based on the results.
4. Monitor the redness moving up the leg and the swelling and pain in the calf.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 7 days.
6. Follow up with the endocrinologist to maintain hemoglobin A1C below 7 and closely monitor blood sugars during medication therapy.

The patient has no further questions or concerns at this time.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports spending time outdoors, including hunting and yard work. He noticed a tick bite on his right knee over a week ago, which has been causing burning and discomfort. He denies fever or chills but reports feeling generally unwell and experiencing headaches since the tick bite.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, Diabetes

MEDICATIONS

Lisinopril 20 mg daily, Metformin 1000 mg twice daily

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, or body aches.
Musculoskeletal: Reports arthritic pain, but no new joint pain since tick bite.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 67 bpm
Temperature: 98.4°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Full range of motion in right knee. Pain to palpation over right anterior knee.
Skin: Bull's-eye rash over right knee, erythema and edema present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Suspected Lyme disease due to tick bite and bull's-eye rash.
- Medical Treatment: Start Doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 3 weeks.
- Diagnostic Testing: Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm diagnosis.

2. Hypertension
- Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily.
- Diagnostic Testing: Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes
- Continue Metformin 1000 mg twice daily.
- Diagnostic Testing: Order Hemoglobin A1c to assess long-term blood sugar control. Order basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.
